repnme.cdata!:
Community participation and low cost
            technology : bringing water supply and sanitation to
            Brazil's urban poor

abstracts.cdata!:
From 1988 to 1996, the Low Income
            Sanitation Technical Assistance Project  (PROSANEAR)
            supported the scaling up of a new approach to delivering
            water supply and sanitation services to the urban poor in
            Brazil. The approach combined cost effective technologies
            with community participation. The project provided one
            million poor people with piped water supply and sanitation.
            It also contributed to building stronger communities and
            showed how water supply and sanitation (WSS) can be an
            integral part of local area development plans.

docna.cdata!:
Community participation and low cost
            technology : bringing water supply and sanitation to
            Brazil's urban poor

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Water Project for Municipalities
            and Low-Income Areas

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Water Project for
            Municipalities and Low-Income Areas for Brazil were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, project sustainability
            was unlikely, Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: utilities have limited experience and
            assign low priority to water and sanitation in poor areas.
            Most utilities have little experience with projects aimed at
            extending services to poor areas, and often are reluctant to
            adopt low-cost technologies and build partnerships with
            community organizations. to address these issues, future
            projects should identify key staff in utilities willing to
            test new technologies and work with poor communities, secure
            support from utility managers and local politicians, and
            promote cultural change in the utilities by investing in
            workshops and field visits from the early stages of project
            preparation. The bulk of resources were allocated to the two
            subprojects in Belem and Rio de Janeiro. Although the Belem
            project was implemented satisfactorily, the Rio project
            suffered delays that were reflected in overall project
            performance. The allocation of resources should recognize
            the potential for weak performance by taking into account
            the implementation capacity of sub-borrowers and the
            commitment and stability of top managers in the
            participating utility.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Water Project For Municipalities
            and Low-income Areas

abstracts.cdata!:
The Water Project for Municipalities and
            Low-Income Areas is the first stage of a long-term program
            to extend water, waste water and solid waste services to
            poverty areas of urban centers   (PROSANEAR) and to expand
            water and sewerage systems in cities with municipally owned
            and operated water utilities.  The Bank loan is a combined
            operation:  sectoral for PROSANEAR, and a project loan for
            the municipality of Campinas in the State of Sao Paulo.  The
            project consists of two main components:  one for  (a) low
            income areas which will improve health and environmental
            conditions by providing water and sanitation services to the
            extremely poor urban families; and (b) an expansion of the
            City of Campinas water supply to eliminate existing water
            rationing.  The low income areas sector component consists
            of:  (a) a group of subprojects benefitting approximately
            200,000 and 700,000 low income urban population with water
            and sewerage services, respectively; (b) provision of
            complementary sanitation services; and a (c) technical
            assistance program for PROSANEAR and for increasing the
            evaluation and supervision capabilities of the Federal
            Savings Bank (CEF). The Campinas component consists of works
            to improve and expand the city's water supply system to
            meet demand through 2002 benefitting more than 860,000 people.

            to extend water, waste water and solid waste services to
